body: VOTE +1 and merged via CTR as it's only a test dependency.

i'm not sure how others feel, but if this PR has reached the same level of compatibility as python (which doesn't cover all the serializers even as of today), I think it should be evaluated for merge for release of 3.5.3.
@tkolanko i just thought i'd follow up on this PR which seems to pass CI builds now. is this done from your perspective?
I believe all items have been addressed at this point for this PR.  VOTE +1
@bechbd looks like you need to rebase this - but other than that VOTE +1
merged - thanks for noticing and fixing that

Hi, I still have in plans to finish with some types like TraversalStrategy and BulkSet, as I see, according to gremlin-javascript and the tests, it’s important to implement them. Also, I have some technical concerns regarding numeric types (I was planning to discuss it with you).

My apologies, but my plans have been postponed due to my neighbour f(r)iend has been throwing rocks into my garden, breaking my house's windows, and trying to break through my doors.

If you want, please, continue according to your plans, i.e. merge and so on.
@ihoro there are a lot of people that are shocked by your neighbor and are hoping he is made to stop very soon. take care.
@ihoro hope you and your family stay safe

> @tkolanko i just thought i'd follow up on this PR which seems to pass CI builds now. is this done from your perspective?

Yeah, good on my side if @jorgebay is good with it
@spmallette I think this will need to wait until after 3.5.3 so I can make the changes @jorgebay requested

I'll leave it open for a few more hours, to give the opportunity for other committers to chime in.

If there aren't any remarks by then, I'll merge it.

Landed in https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/commit/14b1fe003f41ef464090506f9d6e89f58a3f53c9 on `3.5-dev`

Thanks @tkolanko !!!

> Only thing missing is reference documentation update.

do you intend to add the reference documentation for `call()` and `element()` on this PR or are you trying to merge this first?
Finished with a first pass of this - one final thing i noticed...i didn't see gherkin tests for the new `element()` step.

Thanks for taking care of this! 

I like prettier but given that is a codebase that's been around for sometime, is hard to implement a strict set of rules.

I would remove prettier rules and include [eslint:recommended](https://eslint.org/docs/rules/), with quotes: single and a few more that you feel that would help to unify the codebase. fwiw I've used these ones in the past on an old codebase: https://github.com/datastax/nodejs-driver/blob/master/.eslintrc.js

Another thing to have in mind would be to only include rules which errors can automatically be fixed (no manual changes).

Rebased, comments addressed (element() gherkin tests added).

I need to talk to Kelvin about the reference doc. Best to just merge this if it's ready.

> I believe all items have been addressed at this point for this PR. VOTE +1

I missed this one. My concern about using `regex` as a syntax was not addressed.

I believe your issue was satisfied by documentation which you wrote was a way to settle it with: "Continue using TextP.regex() syntax but clarify the behaviour explicitly".

https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/pull/1542/files#diff-aa69bbbf8224e408ea19bf3df1466e16e6309bcfb241f68b578032d9fbbbd48dR4204-R4214

https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/pull/1542/files#diff-a523495c08b5b75fe43826198bab44206a235fc4af4ffc7a40bc684cf817fc71R484-R503

> Add queries in process suite integration tests for these steps.

I'd agree that `element()` should probably have at least some process suite tests. doing that for `call()` seems somewhat questionable since they are a bit TinkerGraph specific, right (I almost wonder if they need to be in the Gherkin suite at all and not just live in `tinkergraph-gremlin`? 

by 3.7.0 hopefully we can just be on gherkin and not have to duplicate tests anymore.

> Add the new types such a ServiceRegistry to the serializers. A general question I have is around how the serializers (particularily graphbinary) will recognize the new tokens added in this reviews.

I don't think we need serializers added, Maybe I'm not thinking of something but users are not sending `SeviceRegistry` instances back and forth during remote Gremlin calls. It's like JanusGraph users not working with remote instances of the management API. 

There might be some need to add these classes for Gryo to suit OLAP sorts of cases. I assume `call()` will work fine in OLAP...we should probably test to be sure and if it doesn't document it. A test would quickly demonstrate if serialization uses cases aren't happy.
merged with eefa13b7f16079d7cd8105331ea137e52737c560 to 3.5-dev/master - thank you!

Just to echo what Stephen said:

> Following things are missing from this review. Are you planning to pick them up as follow-up tasks?
> 
> 1. Add queries in process suite integration tests for these steps.
> 2. Add the new types such a ServiceRegistry to the serializers. A general question I have is around how the serializers (particularily graphbinary) will recognize the new tokens added in this reviews.

1. We decided to skip process suite tests in favor of just feature tests. Especially since these tests are only testable via Tinkergraph. That's why I put them directly in the Tinkergraph package.
2. All the ServiceRegistry stuff is part of the Graph API, not part of Gremlin or the remoting API.
@FlorianHockmann - are you able to approve running the workflows for this PR?

This change also includes some adjustments to the grammar to allow for `Map` definition to be a bit more Groovy-like. In particular, it allows for this type of parsing:

```groovy
[a: 100, "b", 200, id: 300, (T.label): 'person')]
```

It is of note, that unlike Groovy, an enum value like `id` will take precedence as the enum rather than the `String` value. If you want the string value to override the enum it should be placed in quotes.
Please include a CHANGELOG but other than that: VOTE +1

> I believe your issue was satisfied by documentation which you wrote was a way to settle it with: "Continue using TextP.regex() syntax but clarify the behaviour explicitly".
> 
> https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/pull/1542/files#diff-aa69bbbf8224e408ea19bf3df1466e16e6309bcfb241f68b578032d9fbbbd48dR4204-R4214
> 
> https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/pull/1542/files#diff-a523495c08b5b75fe43826198bab44206a235fc4af4ffc7a40bc684cf817fc71R484-R503

Perhaps I should have clarified myself. I still wanted to have a discussion on option 1 vs. option 2 that I suggested in the comment https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/pull/1542#discussion_r782965129 . I would have favoured option 2. Nevertheless, I would like to understand the advantages of choosing option 1 over option 2 here.
@FlorianHockmann will it be possible to back-port this to 3.4.latest drivers as well? Not sure things are at in the release cycle.

> Please include a CHANGELOG

done

> will it be possible to back-port this to 3.4.latest drivers as well?

Our current plan is to not release another version of the 3.4 line at the moment. 3.5.0 was released in May 2021 already so there should have been enough time to update.
If there's a critical bug in 3.4 that needs to be fixed, then we could probably reconsider. But I would not consider this bug here to be critical.
@harrisonhjones Thanks for the feedback! We have incorporated it into current working branch. I am going to merge this pull request and open a pull request with the new changes.

I don't have a lot of technical advantages of 1 over 2 of list, but I don't find 2 more compelling than 1 either to spend time reworking it. @krlawrence who did most of the PR indicated earlier in this discussion that he preferred the naming he chose and it is consistent with what the TinkerPop graph community has been used to seeing since 2015 with Titan to JanusGraph to DataStax Graph.  Personally, I'm fine to stick with it on those grounds.

Merging this causes trouble with Docker which will need the python version bumped in the image. Ultimately we should probably move from xenial to bionic and fix a ton of little hacks in the python environment in there. Would also be nice go to sdkman for java environment stuff. Leaving this item open until it can dealt with it properly.

Something that was raised that is worth calling out:
The Godog tests will not currently run through docker. We haven't set up the server to run custom configurations in docker yet, we expect to have this capability in for the next milestone (MS 5).

If you would like to test this yourself, please use the following configuration file:
```
# Licensed to the Apache Software Foundation (ASF) under one
# or more contributor license agreements.  See the NOTICE file
# distributed with this work for additional information
# regarding copyright ownership.  The ASF licenses this file
# to you under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the
# "License"); you may not use this file except in compliance
# with the License.  You may obtain a copy of the License at
#
#   http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0
#
# Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing,
# software distributed under the License is distributed on an
# "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY
# KIND, either express or implied.  See the License for the
# specific language governing permissions and limitations
# under the License.

host: localhost
port: 8182
evaluationTimeout: 30000
channelizer: org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.server.channel.WebSocketChannelizer
graphs: {
  graph: conf/tinkergraph-empty.properties,
  classic: conf/tinkergraph-empty.properties,
  modern: conf/tinkergraph-empty.properties,
  crew: conf/tinkergraph-empty.properties,
  grateful: conf/tinkergraph-empty.properties,
  sink: conf/tinkergraph-empty.properties
}
scriptEngines: {
  gremlin-groovy: {
    plugins: { org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.server.jsr223.GremlinServerGremlinPlugin: {},
               org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.tinkergraph.jsr223.TinkerGraphGremlinPlugin: {},
               org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.jsr223.ImportGremlinPlugin: {classImports: [java.lang.Math], methodImports: [java.lang.Math#*]},
               org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.jsr223.ScriptFileGremlinPlugin: {files: [scripts/generate-all.groovy]}}}}
serializers:
  - { className: org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.driver.ser.GraphSONMessageSerializerV3d0, config: { ioRegistries: [org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.tinkergraph.structure.TinkerIoRegistryV3d0] }}        # application/json
  - { className: org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.driver.ser.GraphBinaryMessageSerializerV1 }                                                                                                           # application/vnd.graphbinary-v1.0
  - { className: org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.driver.ser.GraphBinaryMessageSerializerV1, config: { serializeResultToString: true }}                                                                 # application/vnd.graphbinary-v1.0-stringd
processors:
  - { className: org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.server.op.session.SessionOpProcessor, config: { sessionTimeout: 28800000 }}
  - { className: org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.server.op.traversal.TraversalOpProcessor, config: { cacheExpirationTime: 600000, cacheMaxSize: 1000 }}
metrics: {
  consoleReporter: {enabled: true, interval: 180000},
  csvReporter: {enabled: true, interval: 180000, fileName: /tmp/gremlin-server-metrics.csv},
  jmxReporter: {enabled: true},
  slf4jReporter: {enabled: true, interval: 180000}}
strictTransactionManagement: false
idleConnectionTimeout: 0
keepAliveInterval: 0
maxInitialLineLength: 4096
maxHeaderSize: 8192
maxChunkSize: 8192
maxContentLength: 65536
maxAccumulationBufferComponents: 1024
resultIterationBatchSize: 64
writeBufferLowWaterMark: 32768
writeBufferHighWaterMark: 65536
ssl: {
  enabled: false}
```
And make sure you have this generate-all.groovy file as linked in the above config. (Note you must unzip it, it is zipped because GitHub won't allow groovy uploaded directly).
[generate-all.groovy.zip](https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/files/8307540/generate-all.groovy.zip)

Thank for making the change. Looks good to me.

Vote +1.
@jorgebay I made some additional changes regarding eslint rules and formatting options. Can you please take a look whenever you have a moment.
I'll merge it tomorrow, if there isn't further feedback.
@jorgebay Should we add `npm run lint` to the CI checks as well?
Ideally yes, but it's not a blocker.
Thanks @vkagamlyk, I propagated this to master as well.
Thanks for this @sputnik13 - I am going to propagate this to master then merge this PR.
Looks awesome! thanks @tkolanko !

New pull request for gremlin-go branch against 3.5-dev is coming up. With that in mind I am going to close this pull request.

The comments which were not addressed in this pull request have been migrated to that pull request's description.
The generated docs also look good to me, so: VOTE +1
a CHANGELOG entry would be nice - other than that VOTE +1
nice addition -  would be good to add some Upgrade Documentation to call attention to this feature, but other than that VOTE +1

> We are missing integration tests against the server (unless I missed something), which can validate the client behaviour in scenario such as:

I'm not sure that we can do this right now. The only driver that has any tests like this is Java and that is because the test setup is such that we can easily start/stop/reconfigure Gremlin Server. There is no such mechanism to do so for non-JVM language variants. I do think this sort of testing is important but it will imply a whole range of test framework development to allow this to happen and I'm not sure what that would look like as it would require per-test mechanisms for that start/stop/reconfigure functionality. 

Unless there is an easy way to do this that I'm not aware of I'd say that such testing would have to be part of a different/larger body of work which builds a Gherkin-like integration test framework for driver behaviors that would cover connection management, sessions, etc.

> would be good to add some Upgrade Documentation to call attention to this feature

Oh right, I only looked at the PR that added the translator to Python and didn't see any upgrade docs there, but the upgrade docs for 3.5.0 definitely had them:
https://tinkerpop.apache.org/docs/current/upgrade/#_translators

edit: Pushed an updated commit which contains upgrade docs.

> a CHANGELOG entry would be nice

I thought that this only fixes a bug that probably nobody noticed until now and that it's therefore enough to have the automated changelog entry from the JIRA ticket, but I can of course also add an explicit mention.

i think manual changelog entries are the better accounting of modifications because they often have better wording than the JIRAs and might also be more detailed in terms of changes. the generated JIRA list is just for reference imo
Added the CHANGELOG entry.

> > We are missing integration tests against the server (unless I missed something), which can validate the client behaviour in scenario such as:
> 
> I'm not sure that we can do this right now. The only driver that has any tests like this is Java and that is because the test setup is such that we can easily start/stop/reconfigure Gremlin Server. There is no such mechanism to do so for non-JVM language variants. I do think this sort of testing is important but it will imply a whole range of test framework development to allow this to happen and I'm not sure what that would look like as it would require per-test mechanisms for that start/stop/reconfigure functionality.
> 
> Unless there is an easy way to do this that I'm not aware of I'd say that such testing would have to be part of a different/larger body of work which builds a Gherkin-like integration test framework for driver behaviors that would cover connection management, sessions, etc.

My main concern is that GA status for a component here in this project would mean that users can start using this in production scenarios. However, we can't confidently say that the client is production ready unless we have tested it on various scenarios involving client-server interaction.

> The only driver that has any tests like this is Java and that is because the test setup is such that we can easily start/stop/reconfigure Gremlin Server. There is no such mechanism to do so for non-JVM language variants. 

I understand what we did not have integration tests for other non-java drivers in the past. But we don't have to keep following the same practices from the past if they were incorrect. Given the scope of usage TinkerPop clients has across the industry, I would argue that we need to release well tested and stable software if we are making something GA.

We can still merge this PR into mainline without integration tests and call it Beta (not recommended for production usage) until we have sufficient testing in place. But I don't agree with calling this ready for production use (GA / preview-GA).

Now, as far as how to do the technical implementation goes, we can either do it against the TinkerPop server or a mock WebSocket server. The ultimate aim is to assert the client-server contract, e.g. does the client respect a close WebSocket frame from the server correctly.

**Option A: With live server**

1. Write an API in the server available in debug mode which will trigger the specific test behaviour we want, e.g. close the WS connection with a WS frame.

2. Use a shell script to start the server and then run a go file containing the integration test. The integration test assumes that a server is running on port 8182

3. Invoke the "test" API from point 1 to make the server do the desired behaviour. 

**Option B: With mock WS server** (All the scenarios that I wrote in the PR comment can be handled by a mock WS server)

Gorilla WebSocket library (the same one that client uses in this PR) already has example tests on how to mock a server. See: https://github.com/gorilla/websocket/blob/master/client_server_test.go#L62 

we can mock a server with WebSocket connection similarly and make it send a close websocket to see how the client reacts and assert the reaction. Similarly for other test scenarios I mentioned, we can mock the connection "disconnect" and can mock the "WS handshake timeout" using the mocks. We don't really need a full TinkerPop server to do this.

(Please correct me if I am wrong, there's a lot of files so I might have missed this)
Another missing component from this PR is the handling of Ping WebSocketFrame from the server.

Note that Gremlin server could have [WebSocket Idle monitor enabled](https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/blob/master/gremlin-server/src/main/java/org/apache/tinkerpop/gremlin/server/AbstractChannelizer.java#L170). In such cases, server would detect an idle websocket connection and [send a ping frame](https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/blob/master/gremlin-server/src/main/java/org/apache/tinkerpop/gremlin/server/handler/UnifiedHandler.java#L328) to the client. But this implementation of client does not have a PingFrame handler from the server (and sending a pong websocket frame back).

> My main concern is that GA status for a component here in this project would mean that users can start using this in production scenarios. 

i feel like we have confusion and i'm not sure where it is coming from. i dont think anyone in the community is in favor of calling this "ready for production". that's why it's an "early release" an "alpha" an "preview" a "milestone" a "release candidate" a "beta"....not sure what you want to call it, but it is not going out with an "official" version stamp with "3.5.3" - it will be "v3.5.3-rc1" (or the like). 

we've released in this fashion before and it is designed to allow an easy way for users to consume some new feature before it is fully ready. typically these early releases are not widely promoted. For instance, we don't include the change in the Upgrade Documentation, Reference Documentation, etc.  However we'll likely make mention of it in a mailing list post and or directly contact those whom we know would be interested in giving it an early try knowing it may not be fully baked.

does that clarify the plan better?

> does that clarify the plan better?

Yep. Absolutely. That does make me comfortable with that fact that we don't have integration tests here. Thanks for being patient. Appreciate it! :)

There are a number of little odds/ends that I'd like to push on this, but I think we should focus in on merging it and I can do those changes after the fact. 

VOTE +1

I vote +1 but I am a little concerned about the test coverage. What would be great is if we could run the whole Gherkin test suite through this translator and then back through the DotNetTranslator and then compare the bytecode of the original and round trip version.

+1 but again, it worries me that we hadn't already caught this. See my comment on the GroovyTransalator PR. For each of these translators, we should run the whole Gherkin test suite through them and then compare the bytecode for the original and the translated. Or something like that.

+1

I am very much in favor of this as a general rule: "Simply forward all null arguments to the steps in GraphTraversal so they can be handled there and we don't need to duplicate the logic whether we want to allow null or throw." The language bindings should be "dumb" as far as semantics are concerned, null semantics included.

Using the Gherkin test suite to test the translators definitely sounds good to me. I would probably just execute the scenarios however with the translated code and then compare the results to what is expected in the scenario / feature.
I think not all translations are 1:1 translations. `with()` is for example implemented as `WithStrategy(OptionsStrategy)` in the GLVs which isn't a problem for the translation but it complicates the comparison of just the bytecode.

But we should probably discuss this separately. Do you want to create a ticket for this in JIRA so we don't forget about it?
@FlorianHockmann are you able to take a final look?
This PR looked promising but appears to have stalled. Are you considering completing this work @junshiguo ?

VOTE +1 to get this body of work merged and then doing any additional iteration so that we have a preview version of the client merged in. We have a lot of users looking for Go clients and getting their feedback ASAP will be very beneficial.
VOTE +1

i think i've addressed the issues here. for documentation of `has()` i added some details to the reference docs but ultimately i think we need to grow the[ Gremlin Semantics section](https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/blob/master/docs/src/dev/provider/gremlin-semantics.asciidoc) to cover these sorts of details.

Looks like pytest is no longer updatable, so this is no longer needed.

OK, I won't notify you again about this release, but will get in touch when a new version is available. If you'd rather skip all updates until the next major or minor version, let me know by commenting `@dependabot ignore this major version` or `@dependabot ignore this minor version`. You can also ignore all major, minor, or patch releases for a dependency by adding an [`ignore` condition](https://docs.github.com/en/code-security/supply-chain-security/configuration-options-for-dependency-updates#ignore) with the desired `update_types` to your config file.

If you change your mind, just re-open this PR and I'll resolve any conflicts on it.

I have looked at this at a previous date and am good with the changes.

VOTE+1

Thanks for the change @simonz-bq. The actual change itself looks great, this will make our syntax more natural for users who are used to using things like `Scope.Local` (as opposed to our previous just `gremlingo.Local`).

I noticed:

```
gremlin-go-integration-tests    | driver/cucumber/gremlin.go:35: undefined: gremlingo.Any
gremlin-go-integration-tests    | driver/cucumber/gremlin.go:36: undefined: gremlingo.None
gremlin-go-integration-tests    | driver/cucumber/gremlin.go:41: undefined: gremlingo.None
gremlin-go-integration-tests    | driver/cucumber/gremlin.go:44: undefined: gremlingo.None
gremlin-go-integration-tests    | driver/cucumber/gremlin.go:47: undefined: gremlingo.Value
gremlin-go-integration-tests    | driver/cucumber/gremlin.go:47: undefined: gremlingo.Asc
gremlin-go-integration-tests    | driver/cucumber/gremlin.go:48: undefined: gremlingo.Label
```
